channel.title: Environment Variable Setter by Lin
channel.description:
[quote="Lin, post:1, topic:284234"]Well, I've noticed SO many people have trouble on this part. That's why I made this. You browse for your JDK folder and click Apply! Done!
Screenshot: [img]http://img520.imageshack.us/img520/5896/javaev.png[/img]
So you don't fuck up, it checks if you've selected the right folder. It does this by checking if the folder starts with "jdk", and it has some of the files in the bin folder that the JDK comes with.
If you've already got your JDK set, it will prompt you to continue. If you do, it'll just write it to the line.
At the bottom textboxes, you can see what was loaded, and what will be saved. This is good if you don't trust it.
So, the download... [size=16pt][b][url=http://www.mediafire.com/?ctfcgg0mmdu]DOWNLOAD HERE[/url][/b][/size]
Oh and finally, you need the .NET Framework 2.0 or higher (Meaning atleast Windows 2000 SP4). I developed it using C# .NET 2005. And I also didn't feel like changing the icon.
If you're totally lost on what to do, follow these instructions.
[b]1.[/b] Open the program. [b]2.[/b] Click on the "Search" button. [b]3.[/b] Navigate to your "JDK" folder. It starts at "C:\Program Files\Java". Basically, go there and click the folder that starts with "jdk". [b]4.[/b] If you did it right, it won't give you any warnings. [b]5.[/b] Click the "Apply" button. If done right, it should say "Successfully changed!" :D
Congratulations!! You did it!!!
[b]Note:[/b] You must have permissions to edit your environment variables. For example, if you're using Windows Vista, you must run under an Administrator account.
~Lin[/quote]
Seems like a decent program that might be of use here. Original link: http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,375681.0.html

item.title: Environment Variable Setter by Lin
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I don’t understand why this is such a hard task. Maybe it’s the lack of conceptual understanding of what the path variable is and does.
All you’re doing by changing the variable is saying ‘when I type an executable’s name (i.e., java or javac) I want you to search in all of the folders that are in the path’. So by adding to the path you’re adding to the list of places to be searched.

Read full topic

item.title: Environment Variable Setter by Lin
item.dc:creator: @yong_min yong min
item.description:
@yong_min wrote:

Ballerr:

How do we use this… Explain more?

Did you actually read the text that was posted?

1. Open the program. 2. Click on the "Search" button. 3. Navigate to your "JDK" folder. It starts at "C:\Program Files\Java". Basically, go there and click the folder that starts with "jdk". 4. If you did it right, it won't give you any warnings. 5. Click the "Apply" button. If done right, it should say "Successfully changed!"

item.title: Environment Variable Setter by Lin
item.dc:creator: @Peter Peeter
item.description:
@Peter wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:1, topic:284234”]Well, I’ve noticed SO many people have trouble on this part. That’s why I made this. You browse for your JDK folder and click Apply! Done!

Screenshot:

So you don’t fuck up, it checks if you’ve selected the right folder. It does this by checking if the folder starts with “jdk”, and it has some of the files in the bin folder that the JDK comes with.

If you’ve already got your JDK set, it will prompt you to continue. If you do, it’ll just write it to the line.

At the bottom textboxes, you can see what was loaded, and what will be saved. This is good if you don’t trust it.

So, the download…
[size=16pt]DOWNLOAD HERE[/size]

Oh and finally, you need the .NET Framework 2.0 or higher (Meaning atleast Windows 2000 SP4). I developed it using C# .NET 2005. And I also didn’t feel like changing the icon.

If you’re totally lost on what to do, follow these instructions.

1. Open the program.
2. Click on the “Search” button.
3. Navigate to your “JDK” folder. It starts at “C:\Program Files\Java”. Basically, go there and click the folder that starts with “jdk”.
4. If you did it right, it won’t give you any warnings.
5. Click the “Apply” button. If done right, it should say “Successfully changed!”

Congratulations!! You did it!!!

Note: You must have permissions to edit your environment variables. For example, if you’re using Windows Vista, you must run under an Administrator account.

~Lin[/quote]

Seems like a decent program that might be of use here. Original link: http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,375681.0.html
